oai_dc:dc.dc:title: I'd like to make a suggestion, Mr. Kennedy, circa 1963
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: An original political cartoon drawing created by Jack Knox, the Nashville Banner editorial cartoonist from the mid-1940s to early 1970s. As John Q. Public looks on, President John F. Kennedy holds a giant pair of scissors. One blade of the scissors is real ("Solid Tax-Cut Plan"), but the other blade is just a strip of paper ("Flimsy Budget Cut Suggestions"). Many Americans were opposed to President Kennedy's tax plan reform proposed to Congress in 1963, with a concern about the impact on the national economy. The increase in federal budget expenditures on defense spending became controversial with proponents of domestic spending. On February 26, 1964, the Kennedy tax cut was enacted as the United States Revenue Act of 1964, signed by President Lyndon Johnson. It was one of the largest tax cuts in the post-WWII era. Forms part of the Jack Knox Political Cartoon Collection. 1 original cartoon drawing : b & w ; 16.25 x 24 in.
